Lessons in Style, Humor, and Resilience: A Deep Dive into Sakamoto desu ga? 

As anime continues to evolve as a storytelling medium, few shows have managed to blend humor, style, and life lessons quite like Sakamoto desu ga? (also known as Havenâ€™t You Heard? Iâ€™m Sakamoto). For anyone whoâ€™s a fan of witty character development and comedic brilliance, this show is a gem that not only entertains but also provides valuable insights into navigating lifeâ€™s challenges with grace.

Here are a few takeaways from the unforgettable protagonist, Sakamoto, that resonate beyond the screen:

Confidence is Key: Sakamoto's unwavering self-assurance teaches us that embracing who we are, no matter how unconventional, is powerful. His ability to stay calm and collected in any situation is a true example of maintaining confidence under pressure.

Embrace Your Uniqueness: Sakamotoâ€™s styleâ€”whether in his impeccable fashion or his quirky actionsâ€”reminds us to embrace what makes us stand out. It's a lesson in authenticity and leadership.

The Power of Humor: The series brilliantly combines slapstick humor and subtle wit. It reminds us that laughter, even in the most unlikely situations, can break down barriers and connect people in meaningful ways.

Resilience in the Face of Adversity: No matter how many challenges Sakamoto faces, he handles each one with composure, making it clear that resilience and adaptability are traits we should all nurture.

Whether youâ€™re looking for a good laugh or an insightful reminder of how to approach life with style, Sakamoto desu ga? is a must-watch. It's more than just an animeâ€”it's a masterclass in cool, with a sprinkle of inspiration that can be applied in both personal and professional settings.

Exactly! Sanchita brings up a crucial challenge in healthcare marketing - what happens when your client is unresponsive?

Do you pause, wait, and risk losing momentum? Or do you find ways to keep driving visibility, engagement, and patient bookings despite the silence?

Marketing doesnâ€™t stop just because approvals do. Patients are still searching. Competitors are still active. The cost of inaction? Lost opportunities.

So whatâ€™s the solution?
1. Control what you can - Create no-approval-needed, high-value content.
2. Leverage local SEO & ads - Patients searching for care donâ€™t need approvals to find you.
3. Automate patient engagement - Reduce friction, increase appointments.
4. Show results, not requests - Data can turn even disengaged clients into believers.

In my experience, waiting for approvals is a choice. Taking action is a strategy.

Great perspective, Sanchita!
postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely agree! Proactive strategies can transform challenges into opportunities. Lets keep the momentum going for patient engagement!

Gemini 2.0 â€“ Can Googleâ€™s Free Models Challenge ChatGPT? 

1/  Google just dropped three Gemini 2.0 AI models for freeâ€”but can they compete with ChatGPT/DeepSeek?

Letâ€™s dissect their strengths, flaws, and why Googleâ€™s playing catch-up. 

Gemini 2.0 Flash â€ï¸:

- Multimodal (text, images, video, audio)
- 1M-token context window (vs ChatGPTâ€™s 128K)
- Optimized for speed & low latency

But in my tests, it choked on complex queries. Perfect for quick weather checks, useless for research papers. 

Flash Thinking Experimental :

â€¢ Shows step-by-step reasoning before answers
â€¢ Same 1M-token limit, but failed basic 2-page doc analysis
â€¢ Transparency â‰  accuracy
DeepSeekâ€™s version is smootherâ€”Gemini feels like a beta test. 

Flash Thinking Exp with App-Integrated Model:

Leverages Googleâ€™s ecosystem (YouTube, Maps, Search). Example:

â€œFind NYC coffee shops open past midnight with vegan optionsâ€ â†’ cross-references Maps + reviews. But outputs felt recycled from existing toolsâ€”no wow factor. ï¸

Why Free? 

â€¢ Pressure from DeepSeek/Qwenâ€™s free tiers
â€¢ ChatGPTâ€™s dominance in advanced tasks
â€¢ Google needs market share fast

Their play: accessibility over excellence. But will casual users care about AI wars?

The Good:
â€¢ Built-in Android assistant = seamless quick queries
â€¢ Gemini Deep Research (paid tool) crushes academic papers

The Bad:
â€¢ Surface-level answers
â€¢ Reliability issues in multi-step reasoning
â€¢ No killer feature vs competitors 

Verdict:

As an Android user, I keep Gemini for quick tasks (emails, simple math).

ChatGPT/DeepSeek still rule. Googleâ€™s models are a solid entry pointâ€”but power users will look elsewhere.

Your Move:

Would you trade depth for speed? Or stick with proven tools? Letâ€™s debate below!  Follow for more AI breakdowns.

postsData.content:
A must for customer facing documents...

Get a second set of eyes on it! This additional step isn't meant to slow down the speed of business in fact, it can ensure it stays moving forward.

For first time documents- have your
person/team take a look at it and ensure it has the right tone and has the professional impact it needs to carry once it goes out to the customer.

Once you have it reviewed and improved by your team, it's ready to share and it won't work against you or the organization. I've seen documents go out that don't speak to the level of skill or expertise the owner actually has.

Remember, that document speaks for you when you're not there to
yourself.

Refresher your documents- if you've been using the same template for a while, it's time to get another perspective and see if it is still
the customer and your organization in the best possible way.

Sometimes we outgrow our documents and that's a good thing! Update it and
a new version.

Consider sharing the documents you use with other departments so you can evaluate how they fit into the workflow of the entire organization. This can help prevent duplication of the same workload and streamline internal communication.

Lastly- save the document in the customer's profile in your
. If there is a document sent or received by a customer, upload it! It will help you in the future and the organization as a whole right now.

Do you have an internal document review process? How often do you refresh and improve templates you use frequently?

The most dangerous SaaS metric isnâ€™t churn or CAC.
Itâ€™s the invisible money youâ€™re leaving on the table.

Most companies track:
â†’ Revenue per customer
â†’ Gross margin
â†’ Contract value

Good, but not enough.
The smart signals?

â†’ Value-to-price gap (how much value you create vs. capture).
â†’ Impact multiplier (how deeply your product changes their business).
â†’ Transformation ROI (how much they gain vs. how little they pay).

If customers get 50x value but only pay 2x more, youâ€™re not pricing strategically.

Youâ€™re subsidizing their success.
The premium paradox: higher prices reduce friction because they:
â†’ Signal confidence
â†’ Attract serious buyers
â†’ Filter out resource-draining customers

If everyone thinks your price is reasonable, youâ€™re undercharging.
Stop measuring what customers pay.
Start measuring the gap between your price and their transformation.

AI Deconstructed: Breaking Down Key AI Domains

AI is transforming the world through various subfields. Hereâ€™s a structured breakdown of its key components:

1. Computer Vision
Gives AI the ability to process visual data, recognizing images, detecting objects, tracking movements, and generating images.

2. Robotics
Combines AI with physical systems to enable autonomous movement, human-robot interaction, and task automation, from robotic arms to path planning.

3. Machine Learning
The foundation of AI, allowing computers to learn from data through supervised, unsupervised, and reinforcement learning, as well as anomaly detection.

4. Ethics and Safety in AI
Focuses on responsible AI development, addressing fairness, bias detection, privacy, transparency, and legal compliance.

5. Natural Language Processing (NLP)
Enables machines to understand, generate, and interpret human language through tasks like speech recognition, translation, sentiment analysis, and chatbots.

Matthew S.

postsData.content:
What is everyone talking about today? Super Bowl Ads.



Anything crazy generates likes / clicks / eyeballs / advertisers. It's like moths getting attracted to a candle - they know that they will burn up but the light is just so enticing. They can't help themselves. It will be all over in under 48 hours.

Taking a cue from other publications - I am going to use the TRENDING, HAS BEEN, and CHARLIE BROWN monikers to make it easy to understand.

TRENDING:
AI generated content. Why pay for expensive actors when you can hire a computer? As much as contracts stipulate that this needs to be controlled, I think companies will try ways to get more while paying less. I predict that the next Super Bowl will have at least one fully AI produced ad: from start to finish. Yes, there are some AI components in the current batch. I am predicting that there will be more. As in CMO will hire a fully AI video startup and it will spit out the commercial to the company which is airing the Super Bowl. There used to be a disclaimer "no animals were harmed in the making of this commercial". Soon there will be "no humans were harmed nor involved with the making of this commercial". There is potential for some amazing things.


HAS BEEN:
There are so many different things I have heard and seen for this category. Here is a big one: very very very few people will change their thinking, consumption behavior, or literally anything else based upon a 30 second ad during the Super Bowl. Are you an Apple or Google person? 99.999% you will continue (until there is a very large reason not to). Do you drink Bud Lite or Millers Lite or Budweiser or any other alcohol? Unless you were in a situation where you could not get your "preferred libation, you are very unlikely to try something else". Even if a frog or a horse talks to you. And no I can not hear you now.


CHARLIE BROWN:
Companies will continue to spend gobs of money to play the game of "coocoo marketing". Or some of you might recognize this as "whack-a-mole". The point is that the company disappears and then reappears randomly somewhere else (normally where the customers and employees least expect it to). Some companies use the Super Bowl as a "coming out opportunity to introduce their brand to the public". And then they disappear. Poof! It would have been better to hire a small agency to create a long term play to consistently get in front of their ideal customer (not just any Tom/Dick/Harry). Please see image of the Whack-A-Mole game. Go try to kick the ball, Charlie Brown - you are going to fall down and wonder where it went. And so the eyes and minds of the consumers will be on to the next thing and forget about you.
postsData.commentAdded: Interesting insights! The evolving landscape of ads, especially with AI, will definitely shape the future of brand storytelling. Exciting times ahead!

postsData.content:
Your student marketing fails because you still treat it as a single category.

As if an 18-year-old freshman living in a dorm has the same needs as a 30-year-old part-time student with two kids.

This oversimplification is costing brands millions.

Look at the real diversity in today's student population:

- First-generation students prioritizing essential electronics and academic materials
- International students seeking brands that understand their cultural preferences
- Working students who value convenience and time-saving solutions
- Parent-students balancing family budgets with educational needs

This isn't just about demographic segments.

It's about understanding fundamentally different lifestyles, values, and purchasing behaviors.

When we embrace this complexity, everything changes.

Our messaging becomes more authentic.
Our targeting gets sharper.
Our ROI improves.

The most successful student marketing campaigns I've analyzed this year all share one thing:

They treat student diversity as a core strategy, not an afterthought.

Stop treating "student marketing" as a single category.

Start treating it as multiple markets that happen to intersect in the education space.

Your campaigns will be better for it.

A better way to measure intelligence in a cognitive â€˜reasoningâ€™ system isnâ€™t just accuracy (as depicted in the repost)â€”itâ€™s adaptive efficiency: 

1/ Generalization Under Constraint â†’ Not just OOD accuracy, but how efficiently the system **reconstructs missing information** and adapts with minimal data.

2/ Self-Directed Optimization â†’ Does the system actively reshape its own learning process to minimize uncertainty rather than passively fitting data?

3/ Energy Efficiency of Inference â†’ True intelligence compresses information**, reducing the computational cost of solving new problems.

4/ Meta-Learning & Self-Verification â†’ Can the system evaluate its own uncertainty**, verify its reasoning, and improve autonomously?

5/ Transfer & Compositionalityâ†’ The ability to synthesize new knowledge from existing priors, forming structured representations that scale.


TL;DR: Intelligence isnâ€™t just about answersâ€”itâ€™s about how efficiently a system **restructures its knowledge, minimizes energy, and refines itself in the face of uncertainty.

postsData.content:
Don't indulge. Delay, and you will be successful.

One of the world's most famous experiments is the Marshmallow Test.

In the late 1960s and early 1970s, psychologist Walter Mischel,
conducted this experiment at Stanford University.

Children were given a marshmallow.

They could eat it immediately and get only one, or wait 15 minutes until the professor returned and get two.

Decades later, researchers followed up with these children.

The findings were astonishing.

Those who waited for the professor and delayed gratification,

ended up being more successful in various aspects of life.


They had higher SAT scores, lower levels of substance abuse, better social skills, and,

overall better life outcomes than those who ate the marshmallow immediately.

The same is true in life.
If we indulge in every desire, there is no scope for growth.
The mind runs its whims and fancies, and we keep chasing them.

Resist immediate gratification.
Build patience. This is the key to long-term success.

Delay your indulgence. Act with intention.

The rewards will follow. Inevitably.

In the Patanjali's Yoga Sutras, there is a wonderful verse to manage craving:

Rather than settling into a state of quiet, receptive awareness, the mind becomes caught up in debates, rationalizations, and mental chatter. This habitual engagement in thought can prevent the dissolution of the mindâ€™s fluctuations (vrittis), which Patanjali describes as the root of our suffering and distraction.

In essence, when faced with internal or external conflicts, the mind instinctively â€œtalksâ€ its way through the discomfort instead of â€œsitting withâ€ the experience. This tendency is seen as an impediment to attaining the deep, unconditioned state of Calmnessâ€”a state of clarity and equanimity where the true self can be experienced without the filters of constant analysis.

The Yoga Sutras thus encourage practitioners to recognize and transcend this pattern. By developing practices such as meditation and detachment (vairagya), one learns to quiet the mindâ€™s need to resolve every contradiction through thought, paving the way toward a more profound, unmediated awareness.

postsData.content:
80% of jobs aren't advertised. 

It's a tough market out there right now. Layoffs happen every single day, and there are hundreds if not thousands of applications for each job opening.

It's exhausting.

it doesn't need to be, though.

Here's how to position your LinkedIn profile like a landing page - and drive leads and recruiters into your DMs.

1. Headline = Your Hook
Your job title is not enough. Your headline should instantly communicate:

- What you do
- Who you help
- Why youâ€™re different

Example: Sales Director - I've helped 3 B2B SaaS businesses grow ARR by 246% without increasing headcount.

2. About Section = Your Sales Pitch.
This is not a resume summaryâ€”itâ€™s your chance to sell yourself.

- Speak directly to your ideal employer/client.
- Showcase your wins. (data > adjectives.)
- End with a clear CTA. Example: "DM me if youâ€™re a X looking for Y"

3. Featured Section = Your Portfolio
Think of this as your proof of work.

- Add case studies, projects, or media that showcase your expertise.
- If you post regularly, pin your best-performing expert content here.

4. Experience = Not Just Job Titles
Recruiters skim. Donâ€™t make them guess what you did.

- Bullet point key achievements (with metrics).
- Show results, not responsibilities.
- Use power phrases like â€œGenerated $2M in pipelineâ€ instead of â€œResponsible for sales.â€

5. Engagement = Your SEO
If youâ€™re not active, youâ€™re invisible.

- Comment on industry conversations.
- Post valuable insights weekly.
- Optimise your profile with keywords so recruiters and hiring managers can find you.

6. Skills & Endorsements = Social Proof
There's a reason why Amazon has peer reviews. Leverage yours.

- Get colleagues or past clients to endorse youâ€”it boosts credibility.
- If you have recommendations, pin the best ones to your profile.

7. DM strangers.
Great a list of companies you want to work for. Find the hiring managers for the relevant department. Pull them into a list and DM them with the specifics of what you've done, your expertise and why you're interested in working for them. Ask if there's an opportunity to "work together" (not "find a job") and if not, who do they recommend you speak to?

People want to help. Use them to get where you need to go.

I break down how to write an A* LinkedIn Profile in the LinkedIn Playbook. Download it here:

It's not enough to be the best anymore, you have to be the best known.

Stop waiting to be found, and allow the right people to find you.

postsData.content:
Words Can Be a Weapon of Destruction 

Wow, what a powerful headline. Throughout my lifetime, there have been two instances where words made a profound impact on me. Lessons in life is how I look at it.

The first instance was something my father shared with me repeatedly over the years. Even into my adulthood, while dropping off my sonâ€”his grandchildâ€”for a summer visit, Dad would remind me, "We are no better than anyone else, but we have a responsibility to lead by example." Being a Kurka meant carrying forward a legacy of integrity, respect, and humility. This upbringing taught me that every individual is unique and valuable, and that our differences should be celebrated, not used as a basis for division. It instilled in me a sense of duty to treat everyone with kindness and fairness, and to strive for excellence in all that I do, not for personal gain, but to honor the values passed down to me.

The second instance happened on Sunday, December 18, 2016. We had just lost our home of 21 years to an electrical fire on December 8, 2016. I had escaped the fire in my nightclothes and a bathrobe. My world was upside down and still very confused, but I returned to St. Stephens the Martyr with a grateful and thankful prayer. Upon entering, I heard two middle-aged female parishioners behind me exclaim, â€œOMG, she is wearing blue jeans to Mass. I would never embarrass myself and dishonor the Church.â€ She did not know that I was waiting for insurance money or that we had just moved into a hotel, I was canceling Xfinity, looking for a cell phone and service to replace what was lost. Cutting power, water and trying to just make it through the day.

Her words cut through me like a knife. This woman, whom I did not know, nor did she know me, chose to label me in such a manner. It has been close to ten years, and her words are still destructive within my world.

When my fingers fly across my keyboard, my singular goal is to be educational, enlightening, and a positive force in whatever I am writing about. And should you ever find my writing to be anything less, please call me out and give me a learning opportunity.

Sashaâ€™s Urban Garden website is almost ready to go live in a few weeks. As mentioned before, I am now a nonprofit gardener who aims to resolve food insecurities within my community and help with mental wellbeing by providing fresh-cut flowers to anyone in need of something positive that day.

NURTURE GROWTH â€“ EMBRACE CHANGE & WELLBEING Join me in cultivating hope.

The shortcut to massive personal growth isn't:

â€¢ Taking ice baths
â€¢ Meditating every day
â€¢ "Hacking" your dopamine

It's writing.

I've been writing every day for 10+ years.

These are the 5 unexpected ways writing daily has transformed my mind, actions, and life:

1. Accountability.

Journaling on a daily (or even weekly) basis allows you to:

â€¢ Document your state of mind
â€¢ Write (and rewrite) your goals
â€¢ Compare what you write vs how you act
â€¢ Learn to merge your inner desires with your outer world

There is no better accountability tool.

2. Clarity of feelings.

Everyone talks about how writing leads to clarity of thought.

What doesn't get talked about is how writing leads to clarity of your emotions.

When you force yourself to write how you feel, you peel back the layersâ€”until you find the root of the root.

3. Self-confidence.

I was a very socially anxious, insecure teenager.

And I was terrified of speaking up in class.

But when you write, you practice:

â€¢ Your ideas
â€¢ Your beliefs
â€¢ Your convictions

The more you write, the better you get at articulating them.

4. Natural voice.

So many writers stress over "finding their voice."

But when you write & journal (a lot), your natural voice can't help but appear on the page in front of you.

Even as I write this, I can "hear" how this voice is the same as my journal voice.

It's all me. You learn to trust yourself.

5. Patience.

Writing takes time because thinking takes time.

â€¢ It's not about putting words on the page.
â€¢ It's about stacking thoughts to form a perspective.

When you can learn to be patient with yourself & your thoughts, it's much easier to be patient with others and theirs.
